_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program Approach

Evans Fruit Co., Inc. has implemented the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP, which included written descriptions of all elements for these program requirements.  To strive for a coordinated and affective program particular persons have been identified and assigned responsibility for carrying out the requirements of each element of these programs.  There is however a single person identified who has overall responsibility for the PSM and RMP.  Most all of the program elements are reviewed annually to keep the program current with personnel training and system requirements.  The entire program is scheduled to be reviewed at least every 3 years in a complete documentation compliance audit review.  Any audit recommendations to improve any program elements are addressed in a timely manner.  A process hazard analysis has been done for the entire system, and the hazard analysis will be repeated at least every five years, or more often if required by changes to the system(s).  A follow-up report is also generated and all recommendations from the hazard analysis which are addressed to further improve the safety and integrity of the ammonia refrigeration system.  It is intended that the PSM/RMP for the Tieton Drive Warehouse facility be actively used, reviewed, and improved as needed to assure the safety of the employees, the public, and the environment.  It is expected that by following the work practices that are implemented at the facility only incidental released of ammonia will occurred due to routine maintenance procedures, or normal equipment wear and tear. 



Facility

This facility is used for the storage and packaging of fruit products, primarily apples.  The facility has a combination of controlled atmosphere rooms and non-controlled atmosphere rooms.  The facility is in operation year around from the time freshly picked fruit is brought into the rooms, till the next harvest season begins.  The refrigeration system uses ammonia, which is not only efficien

t but also easily detectable at very low concentrations.  The entire refrigeration system is controlled by a computer, which also provides alarming and auto-dial notification to the refrigeration technician if some control parameter is out of acceptable limits.



Release Considerations

Following program guidelines a "Worse Case" release of ammonia was analyzed.  Also, several alternative (much more likely to occur) releases were considered.  Both the worse and alternate cases were documented in a report.  The alternative releases were in most cases releases that were of potential concern as determined in the "Process Hazard Analysis" of the system and facility.  The information generated from the consideration of the worse and alternative releases is used in developing the emergency action plan for the facility, and for coordination with local emergency responders.  



Five year release history - No Releases

This system has not had any reportable releases of ammonia in the last five year period.  If any actual release occur or even a near miss, an incident investigation would be done to determine the cause, and to find means or methods to reduce the possibility of a similar future occurrence.



Emergency Action Plan

This facility has a written "Emergency Action Plan" that will be followed in the event of any type of emergency, including an ammonia release.  All responses by Evans Fruit employee's and the refrigeration technicians will be "defensive" actions to control and contain an ammonia release until outside responders arrive to take "offensive" actions as appropriate for a release.  Evans Fruit does evacuation drills at least annually with all employees at the facility to assure safe and appropriate actions are done.



Planned Safety Improvement

 This facility holds monthly safety meetings with all Management Staff, and Supervisors where all aspects of safety are discussed in regards to improving and maintaining a safe work environment.  Minutes of thes

e meetings are kept and used to monitor progress toward safety and operational improvement of any items discussed and agreed upon.  Systems and procedures are reviewed and updated; in many cases annually to assure that all operations are being done is a safe and effective manner, and operating procedure will continue to be developed an improved.
